progress.description: if: status == syncing

offset.description: if: status == available

x-amount.description: Coins, in Lovelace. Only relates to 'Ada'. Refer to `assets` for multi-assets wallets instead.

x-stakePoolId.description: A unique identifier for the pool.

x-walletAccountPubkey.description: An extended account public key (public key + chain code)

x-walletId.description: A unique identifier for the wallet

x-poolMetadataSource.description:
Pool metadata source. This sets the metadata fetching strategy.

Possible values are
  * none -> no fetching
  * direct -> direct fetching
  * uri -> use SMASH server

x-credentialPubKey.description: A public key (public key without chain code) for credential - 32 bytes

x-validationLevel.description:
Script validation level. Required validation sifts off scripts that would not
be accepted by the ledger. Recommended level filters out scripts that do not pass
required validation and additionally when:
  * 'all' is non-empty
  * there are redundant timelocks in a given level
  * there are no duplicated verification keys in a given level
  * 'at_least' coeffcient is positive
  * 'all', 'any' are non-empty and `'at_least' has no less elements in the list
     than the coeffcient after timelocks are filtered out.

x-anyAddress.description: A Shelley address representing either enterprise, reward account or delegating address

oneOf.title: Key Hash
oneOf.description: Leaf value for a script designating a required verification key hash.

all.description: Script primitive for which all signing keys corresponding to all list elements' verification keys are expected to make the script valid.

any.description: Script primitive for which a signing key corresponding to any of the list elements' verification keys is expected to make the script valid. It is equivalent to `some` with `"at_least"=1`.

some.description: Script primitive for which at least a given number of signing keys corresponding to the list elements' verification keys are expected to make the script valid.

active_from.description: Transaction is only valid starting at the specified slot number (`≥ active_from`).

active_until.description: Transaction is only valid before the specified slot number (`< active_until`).

pool_metadata_source.description:
Select stake pool metadata fetching strategy:
  - `none` - metadata is not fetched at all,
  - `direct` - metadata is fetched directly URLs registered on chain,
  - `uri` - metadata is fetched from an external Stake-Pool Metadata Aggregation Server (SMASH)

After update existing metadata will be dropped forcing it to re-sync automatically with the new setting.

x-assetName.description:
The asset on-chain type which acts as a sub-identifier within a
policy. Although we call it "asset name", the value needn't be
text, and it could even be empty.

For policies with a single fungible asset item, asset name is
typically an empty string.

This value can be up to 32 bytes of arbitrary data (which is 64
hexadecimal digits).

x-assetPolicyId.description:
A unique identifier of the asset's monetary policy. The policy
controls how assets of this kind are created and destroyed.

The contents are the blake2b-224 hash of the monetary policy
script, encoded in hexadecimal.

x-assetFingerprint.description:
A user-facing short fingerprint which combines the `policy_id` and `asset_name`
to allow for an easier human comparison of assets. Note that it is generally
**not okay** to use this fingerprint as a unique identifier for it is not collision
resistant. Yet within the context of a single wallet, it makes for a (rather)
short user-facing comparison mean.

x-assetMetadataName.description: A human-readable name for the asset. Good for display in user interfaces.

x-assetMetadataAcronym.description:
A human-readable short name for the asset. Good for display in
user interfaces.

x-assetMetadataDescription.description: A human-readable description for the asset. Good for display in user interfaces.

x-assetMetadataUnit.description:
Defines a larger unit for the asset, in the same way Ada is the
larger unit of Lovelace.

decimals.description: The number of digits after the decimal point.

name.description:
The human-readable name for the larger unit of the asset. Used
for display in user interfaces.

x-assetMetadataUrl.description: A URL to the policy's owner(s) or the entity website in charge of the asset.

x-assetMetadataLogo.description:
A base64-encoded `image/png` for displaying the asset. The end image can be expected
to be smaller than 64KB.

x-assetMetadata.title: Native Assets Metadata
x-assetMetadata.description:
status: ⚠ under development

_This field is not implemented yet, and the values will always be empty._ In the Mary era of Cardano, UTxO may contain native assets. These assets are represented on-chain by opaque identifiers which are meaningless to end-users. Therefore, user-facing metadata regarding each token must be stored off-chain, in a metadata registry. Token creators may publish metadata into the registry and client applications can consume these metadata for display to end users. This will work in a similar way to how it is done for stake pool metadata.

name.description: A human-readable name for the asset. Good for display in user interfaces.

description.description: A human-readable description for the asset. Good for display in user interfaces.

acronym.description:
A human-readable short name for the asset. Good for display in
user interfaces.

unit.description:
Defines a larger unit for the asset, in the same way Ada is the
larger unit of Lovelace.

decimals.description: The number of digits after the decimal point.

name.description:
The human-readable name for the larger unit of the asset. Used
for display in user interfaces.

url.description: A URL to the policy's owner(s) or the entity website in charge of the asset.

logo.description:
A base64-encoded `image/png` for displaying the asset. The end image can be expected
to be smaller than 64KB.

x-walletSecondFactor.description: An optional passphrase used to encrypt the mnemonic sentence.

x-walletPassphrase.description: A master passphrase to lock and protect the wallet for sensitive operation (e.g. sending funds)

x-keyExtended.description: Determines whether extended (with chain code) or normal (without chain code) key is requested

x-lenientPassphrase.description: A master passphrase to lock and protect the wallet for sensitive operation (e.g. sending funds)

x-walletPassphraseHash.description:
A hash of master passphrase. The hash should be an output of a Scrypt function with the following parameters:
- logN = 14
- r = 8
- p = 1

x-walletEncryptedRootPrivateKey.description:
A root private key, encrypted using a given passphrase. The underlying key should contain:
- A private key
- A chain code
- A public key

x-walletAddressPoolGap.description:
Number of consecutive unused addresses allowed.

**IMPORTANT DISCLAIMER:** Using values other than `20` automatically makes your wallet invalid with regards to BIP-44 address discovery. It means that you **will not** be able to fully restore
your wallet in a different software which is strictly following BIP-44.

Beside, using large gaps is **not recommended** as it may induce important performance degradations. Use at your own risks.

progress.description: if: status == syncing

x-walletState.description: Whether a wallet is ready to use or still syncing

available.description: Available Ada UTxO balance (funds that can be spent without condition).

reward.description: The Ada balance of the reward account for this wallet.

total.description: Total Ada balance (available balance plus pending change and reward balance).

x-assetQuantity.description: Number of assets for the given `policy_id` and `asset_name`.

x-walletAsset.description:
An asset on the Cardano blockchain. An asset is uniquely identified by
its `policy_id` and `asset_name` (together, these form the _asset id_).

Two assets with the same `asset_name` and `policy_id` are
interchangeable. Yet, different assets with a same `policy_id` but
different `asset_name` are treated as separate assets, as are two
assets with the same `asset_name` but different `policy_id`.

policy_id.description:
A unique identifier of the asset's monetary policy. The policy
controls how assets of this kind are created and destroyed.

The contents are the blake2b-224 hash of the monetary policy
script, encoded in hexadecimal.

asset_name.description:
The asset on-chain type which acts as a sub-identifier within a
policy. Although we call it "asset name", the value needn't be
text, and it could even be empty.

For policies with a single fungible asset item, asset name is
typically an empty string.

This value can be up to 32 bytes of arbitrary data (which is 64
hexadecimal digits).

fingerprint.description:
A user-facing short fingerprint which combines the `policy_id` and `asset_name`
to allow for an easier human comparison of assets. Note that it is generally
**not okay** to use this fingerprint as a unique identifier for it is not collision
resistant. Yet within the context of a single wallet, it makes for a (rather)
short user-facing comparison mean.

The amount of assets available to spend may be less than the total
unspent assets due to transaction change amounts which are yet to

x-transactionInputs.description:
A list of transaction inputs.

`assets` and `address` are always present for `outgoing`
transactions but generally absent for `incoming`
transactions. This information is present on the Cardano explorer,
but is not tracked by the wallet.

A delegation action.

Pool id is only required for "join".

pool.description: A unique identifier for the pool.

x-transactionRedemptionRequest.description:
When provided, attempts to withdraw rewards from the default stake address corresponding to the given mnemonic.

Should the rewards be null or too small to be worth withdrawing (i.e. the cost of adding them into the transaction
is more than their own intrinsic value), the server will reject the request with a `withdrawal_not_worth` error.

withdrawal field    | reward balance | result
---                 | ---            | ---
any recovery phrase | too small      | x Error 403 `withdrawal_not_worth`
any recovery phrase | big enough     | ✓ withdrawal generated

x-transactionWithdrawalRequestSelf.description:
When provided, instruments the server to automatically withdraw rewards from the source wallet when they are deemed
sufficient (i.e. they contribute to the balance for at least as much as they cost).

As a consequence, the resulting transaction may or may not have a withdrawal object. Summarizing:

withdrawal field | reward balance | result
---              | ---            | ---
`null`           | too small      | ✓ no withdrawals generated
`null`           | big enough     | ✓ no withdrawals generated
`"self"`         | too small      | ✓ no withdrawals generated
`"self"`         | big enough     | ✓ withdrawal generated

x-transactionWithdrawals.description: A list of withdrawals from stake addresses.

amount.description: Coins, in Lovelace. Only relates to 'Ada'. Refer to `assets` for multi-assets wallets instead.

x-transactionMetadata.description:
**⚠️ WARNING ⚠️**

_Please note that metadata provided in a transaction will be
stored on the blockchain forever. Make sure not to include any sensitive data,
in particular personally identifiable information (PII)._

Extra application data attached to the transaction.

Cardano allows users and developers to embed their own
authenticated metadata when submitting transactions. Metadata can
be expressed as a JSON object with some restrictions:

1. All top-level keys must be integers between `0` and `2^64 - 1`.

2. Each metadata value is tagged with its type.

3. Strings must be at most 64 bytes when UTF-8 encoded.

4. Bytestrings are hex-encoded, with a maximum length of 64 bytes.

Metadata aren't stored as JSON on the Cardano blockchain but are
instead stored using a compact binary encoding (CBOR).

The binary encoding of metadata values supports three simple types:

* Integers in the range `-(2^64 - 1)` to `2^64 - 1`
* Strings (UTF-8 encoded)
* Bytestrings

And two compound types:

* Lists of metadata values
* Mappings from metadata values to metadata values

It is possible to transform any JSON object into this schema.

However, if your application uses floating point values, they will
need to be converted somehow, according to your
requirements. Likewise for `null` or `bool` values. When reading
metadata from chain, be aware that integers may exceed the
javascript numeric range, and may need special "bigint" parsing.

x-transactionTTL.description:
The TTL (time to live) is the time period in which the transaction
will be accepted into node mempools.

After the TTL has lapsed, the transaction is considered
expired. At this point, nodes will give up on broadcasting the
transaction, and the wallet will release the funds allocated to
the transaction so they can be used for other payments.

The TTL should be long enough that the transaction has time to be
propagated through the network and confirmed, but short enough so
that - in the event of failures - UTxO are returned to the wallet
in a timely manner.

The TTL value is given in seconds. It will be converted to a slot
number internally.

If the TTL is not provided for a payment, a reasonable default
value will be used.

x-stakePoolApparentPerformance.description:
Apparent performance of the stake pool over past epochs. This indicator is computed
using data available to the server. In particular, the server can't reliably know the
stake distribution of past epochs without being during those epochs. The performance
are therefore an average measure that is more accurate for servers that are online
often.

The performance is a float with double-precision which is _typically_ within `0` and `1`:

  - `0` means that a pool is not performing well.
  - `1` means that a pool is performing _as expected_.
  - above `1` means the pool is performing beyond expectations.

Pools that are lucky enough to win most of their slots early in the epoch will tend to look
like they're over-performing for a while. Having a wallet regularly connected to the network
would harmonize the performance and give better results.

epoch_number.description: An epoch is a time period which is divided into slots.

x-stakePoolRetirement.description:
The epoch in which a stake pool retires.

May be omitted if the wallet hasn't yet found a retirement certificate
for this stake pool.

x-stakePoolPledge.description:
Minimal stake amount that a stake pool is willing to honor.

May be omitted if the wallet hasn't found the pool's registration cerificate yet.

x-stakePoolCost.description:
Estimated cost set by the pool operator when registering his pool.
This fixed cost is taken from each reward earned by the pool before splitting rewards between stakeholders.

May be omitted if the wallet hasn't found the pool's registration cerificate yet.

x-stakePoolMargin.description:
Variable margin on the total reward given to an operator before splitting rewards between stakeholders.

May be omitted if the wallet hasn't found the pool's registration cerificate yet.

x-stakePoolSaturation.description:
Saturation-level of the pool based on the desired number of pools aimed by the network.
A value above `1` indicates that the pool is saturated.

The `non_myopic_member_rewards` take oversaturation into account, as specified by the [specs](https://hydra.iohk.io/job/Cardano/cardano-ledger-specs/delegationDesignSpec/latest/download-by-type/doc-pdf/delegation_design_spec).

The saturation is based on the live `relative_stake`. The saturation at the end of epoch e,
will affect the rewards paid out at the end of epoch e+3.

x-non-myopic-member-rewards.description:
The rewards the wallet can expect to receive at the end of an epoch, in the long term, if delegating to
this pool.

For more details, see the
[Design Specification for Delegation and Incentives in Cardano](https://hydra.iohk.io/job/Cardano/cardano-ledger-specs/delegationDesignSpec/latest/download-by-type/doc-pdf/delegation_design_spec)
document.

non_myopic_member_rewards.description:

For more details, see the section "Relative Stake: Active vs Total" in

ApiEraInfo.description:
If and when each era started or will start.

The object is keyed by era names. The values either describe the epoch boundary
when the era starts (can be in the future or in the past), or are null if not yet
confirmed on-chain.

If you need to know the current era, see the `node_era` field of
`GET /network/information`.

> Due to complications with our current tooling, we cannot mark the era names
> as required, but the keys are in fact always present.

items.description:
An asset on the Cardano blockchain. An asset is uniquely identified by
its `policy_id` and `asset_name` (together, these form the _asset id_).

Two assets with the same `asset_name` and `policy_id` are
interchangeable. Yet, different assets with a same `policy_id` but
different `asset_name` are treated as separate assets, as are two
assets with the same `asset_name` but different `policy_id`.

policy_id.description:
A unique identifier of the asset's monetary policy. The policy
controls how assets of this kind are created and destroyed.

The contents are the blake2b-224 hash of the monetary policy
script, encoded in hexadecimal.

asset_name.description:
The asset on-chain type which acts as a sub-identifier within a
policy. Although we call it "asset name", the value needn't be
text, and it could even be empty.

For policies with a single fungible asset item, asset name is
typically an empty string.

This value can be up to 32 bytes of arbitrary data (which is 64
hexadecimal digits).

fingerprint.description:
A user-facing short fingerprint which combines the `policy_id` and `asset_name`
to allow for an easier human comparison of assets. Note that it is generally
**not okay** to use this fingerprint as a unique identifier for it is not collision
resistant. Yet within the context of a single wallet, it makes for a (rather)
short user-facing comparison mean.

quantity.description: Number of assets for the given `policy_id` and `asset_name`.

delegation_action.description:
A delegation action.

Pool id is only required for "join".

pool.description: A unique identifier for the pool.

amount.description: Coins, in Lovelace. Only relates to 'Ada'. Refer to `assets` for multi-assets wallets instead.

ApiGCStatus.description:
Gives an indication if metadata GC checking for delisted pools
has run and if so, when.

Possible values are:
  - not_applicable -> we're currently not querying a SMASH server for metadata
  - not_started -> the GC hasn't started yet, try again in a short while
  - restarting -> the GC thread is currently restarting, try again in short while
  - has_run -> the GC has run successfully

When 'status' is 'restarting' or 'has_run' then the field 'last_run'
is set to the last GC time in UTC.

ApiMaintenanceActionPostData.description:
The maintenance action to carry out, current values are
  - gc_stake_pools -> trigger looking up delisted pools from the remote SMASH server

gc_stake_pools.description:
Gives an indication if metadata GC checking for delisted pools
has run and if so, when.

Possible values are:
  - not_applicable -> we're currently not querying a SMASH server for metadata
  - not_started -> the GC hasn't started yet, try again in a short while
  - restarting -> the GC thread is currently restarting, try again in short while
  - has_run -> the GC has run successfully

When 'status' is 'restarting' or 'has_run' then the field 'last_run'
is set to the last GC time in UTC.

policy_id.description:
A unique identifier of the asset's monetary policy. The policy
controls how assets of this kind are created and destroyed.

The contents are the blake2b-224 hash of the monetary policy
script, encoded in hexadecimal.

asset_name.description:
The asset on-chain type which acts as a sub-identifier within a
policy. Although we call it "asset name", the value needn't be
text, and it could even be empty.

For policies with a single fungible asset item, asset name is
typically an empty string.

This value can be up to 32 bytes of arbitrary data (which is 64
hexadecimal digits).

fingerprint.description:
A user-facing short fingerprint which combines the `policy_id` and `asset_name`
to allow for an easier human comparison of assets. Note that it is generally
**not okay** to use this fingerprint as a unique identifier for it is not collision
resistant. Yet within the context of a single wallet, it makes for a (rather)
short user-facing comparison mean.

metadata.description:
**⚠️ WARNING ⚠️**

_Please note that metadata provided in a transaction will be
stored on the blockchain forever. Make sure not to include any sensitive data,
in particular personally identifiable information (PII)._

Extra application data attached to the transaction.

Cardano allows users and developers to embed their own
authenticated metadata when submitting transactions. Metadata can
be expressed as a JSON object with some restrictions:

1. All top-level keys must be integers between `0` and `2^64 - 1`.

2. Each metadata value is tagged with its type.

3. Strings must be at most 64 bytes when UTF-8 encoded.

4. Bytestrings are hex-encoded, with a maximum length of 64 bytes.

Metadata aren't stored as JSON on the Cardano blockchain but are
instead stored using a compact binary encoding (CBOR).

The binary encoding of metadata values supports three simple types:

* Integers in the range `-(2^64 - 1)` to `2^64 - 1`
* Strings (UTF-8 encoded)
* Bytestrings

And two compound types:

* Lists of metadata values
* Mappings from metadata values to metadata values

It is possible to transform any JSON object into this schema.

However, if your application uses floating point values, they will
need to be converted somehow, according to your
requirements. Likewise for `null` or `bool` values. When reading
metadata from chain, be aware that integers may exceed the
javascript numeric range, and may need special "bigint" parsing.

metadata.title: Native Assets Metadata
metadata.description:
status: ⚠ under development

_This field is not implemented yet, and the values will always be empty._ In the Mary era of Cardano, UTxO may contain native assets. These assets are represented on-chain by opaque identifiers which are meaningless to end-users. Therefore, user-facing metadata regarding each token must be stored off-chain, in a metadata registry. Token creators may publish metadata into the registry and client applications can consume these metadata for display to end users. This will work in a similar way to how it is done for stake pool metadata.

name.description: A human-readable name for the asset. Good for display in user interfaces.

description.description: A human-readable description for the asset. Good for display in user interfaces.

acronym.description:
A human-readable short name for the asset. Good for display in
user interfaces.

unit.description:
Defines a larger unit for the asset, in the same way Ada is the
larger unit of Lovelace.

decimals.description: The number of digits after the decimal point.

name.description:
The human-readable name for the larger unit of the asset. Used
for display in user interfaces.

url.description: A URL to the policy's owner(s) or the entity website in charge of the asset.

logo.description:
A base64-encoded `image/png` for displaying the asset. The end image can be expected
to be smaller than 64KB.

migration_cost.description: Total amount which will be paid as fees for the migration.

leftovers.description: Leftovers dust coins which won't be migrated nor spent as fees.

oneOf.title: Key Hash
oneOf.description: Leaf value for a script designating a required verification key hash.

all.description: Script primitive for which all signing keys corresponding to all list elements' verification keys are expected to make the script valid.

any.description: Script primitive for which a signing key corresponding to any of the list elements' verification keys is expected to make the script valid. It is equivalent to `some` with `"at_least"=1`.

some.description: Script primitive for which at least a given number of signing keys corresponding to the list elements' verification keys are expected to make the script valid.

active_from.description: Transaction is only valid starting at the specified slot number (`≥ active_from`).

active_until.description: Transaction is only valid before the specified slot number (`< active_until`).

validation.description:
Script validation level. Required validation sifts off scripts that would not
be accepted by the ledger. Recommended level filters out scripts that do not pass
required validation and additionally when:
  * 'all' is non-empty
  * there are redundant timelocks in a given level
  * there are no duplicated verification keys in a given level
  * 'at_least' coeffcient is positive
  * 'all', 'any' are non-empty and `'at_least' has no less elements in the list
     than the coeffcient after timelocks are filtered out.

passphrase.description: A master passphrase to lock and protect the wallet for sensitive operation (e.g. sending funds)

encrypted_root_private_key.description:
A root private key, encrypted using a given passphrase. The underlying key should contain:
- A private key
- A chain code
- A public key

passphrase_hash.description:
A hash of master passphrase. The hash should be an output of a Scrypt function with the following parameters:
- logN = 14
- r = 8
- p = 1

extended.description: Determines whether extended (with chain code) or normal (without chain code) key is requested

pool_metadata_source.description:
Select stake pool metadata fetching strategy:
  - `none` - metadata is not fetched at all,
  - `direct` - metadata is fetched directly URLs registered on chain,
  - `uri` - metadata is fetched from an external Stake-Pool Metadata Aggregation Server (SMASH)

After update existing metadata will be dropped forcing it to re-sync automatically with the new setting.

ApiSmashServer.description: A base SMASH uri without endpoint path.

ApiHealthCheck.description:
The status of the SMASH server. Possible values are:

health                  | description
---                     | ---
`"available"`           | server is awaiting your requests
`"unavailable"`         | server is running, but currently unavailable, try again in a short time
`"unreachable"`         | server could not be reached or didn't return a health status
`"no_smash_configured"` | SMASH is currently not configured, adjust the Settings first

withdrawal.description:
When provided, instruments the server to automatically withdraw rewards from the source wallet when they are deemed
sufficient (i.e. they contribute to the balance for at least as much as they cost).

As a consequence, the resulting transaction may or may not have a withdrawal object. Summarizing:

withdrawal field | reward balance | result
---              | ---            | ---
`null`           | too small      | ✓ no withdrawals generated
`null`           | big enough     | ✓ no withdrawals generated
`"self"`         | too small      | ✓ no withdrawals generated
`"self"`         | big enough     | ✓ withdrawal generated

2. Each metadata value is tagged with its type.

3. Strings must be at most 64 bytes when UTF-8 encoded.

4. Bytestrings are hex-encoded, with a maximum length of 64 bytes.

Metadata aren't stored as JSON on the Cardano blockchain but are
instead stored using a compact binary encoding (CBOR).

The binary encoding of metadata values supports three simple types:

* Integers in the range `-(2^64 - 1)` to `2^64 - 1`
* Strings (UTF-8 encoded)
* Bytestrings

And two compound types:

* Lists of metadata values
* Mappings from metadata values to metadata values

It is possible to transform any JSON object into this schema.

However, if your application uses floating point values, they will
need to be converted somehow, according to your
requirements. Likewise for `null` or `bool` values. When reading
metadata from chain, be aware that integers may exceed the
javascript numeric range, and may need special "bigint" parsing.

time_to_live.description:
The TTL (time to live) is the time period in which the transaction
will be accepted into node mempools.

After the TTL has lapsed, the transaction is considered
expired. At this point, nodes will give up on broadcasting the
transaction, and the wallet will release the funds allocated to
the transaction so they can be used for other payments.

The TTL should be long enough that the transaction has time to be
propagated through the network and confirmed, but short enough so
that - in the event of failures - UTxO are returned to the wallet
in a timely manner.

The TTL value is given in seconds. It will be converted to a slot
number internally.

If the TTL is not provided for a payment, a reasonable default
value will be used.

amount.description: Coins, in Lovelace. Only relates to 'Ada'. Refer to `assets` for multi-assets wallets instead.

items.description:
An asset on the Cardano blockchain. An asset is uniquely identified by
its `policy_id` and `asset_name` (together, these form the _asset id_).

Two assets with the same `asset_name` and `policy_id` are
interchangeable. Yet, different assets with a same `policy_id` but
different `asset_name` are treated as separate assets, as are two
assets with the same `asset_name` but different `policy_id`.

policy_id.description:
A unique identifier of the asset's monetary policy. The policy
controls how assets of this kind are created and destroyed.

The contents are the blake2b-224 hash of the monetary policy
script, encoded in hexadecimal.

asset_name.description:
The asset on-chain type which acts as a sub-identifier within a
policy. Although we call it "asset name", the value needn't be
text, and it could even be empty.

For policies with a single fungible asset item, asset name is
typically an empty string.

This value can be up to 32 bytes of arbitrary data (which is 64
hexadecimal digits).

fingerprint.description:
A user-facing short fingerprint which combines the `policy_id` and `asset_name`
to allow for an easier human comparison of assets. Note that it is generally
**not okay** to use this fingerprint as a unique identifier for it is not collision
resistant. Yet within the context of a single wallet, it makes for a (rather)
short user-facing comparison mean.

quantity.description: Number of assets for the given `policy_id` and `asset_name`.

withdrawal.description:
When provided, attempts to withdraw rewards from the default stake address corresponding to the given mnemonic.

Should the rewards be null or too small to be worth withdrawing (i.e. the cost of adding them into the transaction
is more than their own intrinsic value), the server will reject the request with a `withdrawal_not_worth` error.

withdrawal field    | reward balance | result
---                 | ---            | ---
any recovery phrase | too small      | x Error 403 `withdrawal_not_worth`
any recovery phrase | big enough     | ✓ withdrawal generated

withdrawal.description:
When provided, instruments the server to automatically withdraw rewards from the source wallet when they are deemed
sufficient (i.e. they contribute to the balance for at least as much as they cost).

As a consequence, the resulting transaction may or may not have a withdrawal object. Summarizing:

withdrawal field | reward balance | result
---              | ---            | ---
`null`           | too small      | ✓ no withdrawals generated
`null`           | big enough     | ✓ no withdrawals generated
`"self"`         | too small      | ✓ no withdrawals generated
`"self"`         | big enough     | ✓ withdrawal generated

metadata.description:
**⚠️ WARNING ⚠️**

_Please note that metadata provided in a transaction will be
stored on the blockchain forever. Make sure not to include any sensitive data,
in particular personally identifiable information (PII)._

Extra application data attached to the transaction.

Cardano allows users and developers to embed their own
authenticated metadata when submitting transactions. Metadata can
be expressed as a JSON object with some restrictions:

1. All top-level keys must be integers between `0` and `2^64 - 1`.

2. Each metadata value is tagged with its type.

3. Strings must be at most 64 bytes when UTF-8 encoded.

4. Bytestrings are hex-encoded, with a maximum length of 64 bytes.

Metadata aren't stored as JSON on the Cardano blockchain but are
instead stored using a compact binary encoding (CBOR).

The binary encoding of metadata values supports three simple types:

* Integers in the range `-(2^64 - 1)` to `2^64 - 1`
* Strings (UTF-8 encoded)
* Bytestrings

And two compound types:

* Lists of metadata values
* Mappings from metadata values to metadata values

It is possible to transform any JSON object into this schema.

However, if your application uses floating point values, they will
need to be converted somehow, according to your
requirements. Likewise for `null` or `bool` values. When reading
metadata from chain, be aware that integers may exceed the
javascript numeric range, and may need special "bigint" parsing.

time_to_live.description:
The TTL (time to live) is the time period in which the transaction
will be accepted into node mempools.

After the TTL has lapsed, the transaction is considered
expired. At this point, nodes will give up on broadcasting the
transaction, and the wallet will release the funds allocated to
the transaction so they can be used for other payments.

The TTL should be long enough that the transaction has time to be
propagated through the network and confirmed, but short enough so
that - in the event of failures - UTxO are returned to the wallet
in a timely manner.

The TTL value is given in seconds. It will be converted to a slot
number internally.

If the TTL is not provided for a payment, a reasonable default
value will be used.

passphrase.description: A master passphrase to lock and protect the wallet for sensitive operation (e.g. sending funds)

oneOf.description: A public key (public key without chain code) for credential - 32 bytes
oneOf.title: public key
Key Hash
oneOf.description: Leaf value for a script designating a required verification key hash.

all.description: Script primitive for which all signing keys corresponding to all list elements' verification keys are expected to make the script valid.

any.description: Script primitive for which a signing key corresponding to any of the list elements' verification keys is expected to make the script valid. It is equivalent to `some` with `"at_least"=1`.

some.description: Script primitive for which at least a given number of signing keys corresponding to the list elements' verification keys are expected to make the script valid.

active_from.description: Transaction is only valid starting at the specified slot number (`≥ active_from`).

active_until.description: Transaction is only valid before the specified slot number (`< active_until`).

pool_metadata_source.description:
Pool metadata source. This sets the metadata fetching strategy.

Possible values are
  * none -> no fetching
  * direct -> direct fetching
  * uri -> use SMASH server

oneOf.description: Restore from account public key

account_public_key.description: An extended account public key (public key + chain code)

address_pool_gap.description:
Number of consecutive unused addresses allowed.

**IMPORTANT DISCLAIMER:** Using values other than `20` automatically makes your wallet invalid with regards to BIP-44 address discovery. It means that you **will not** be able to fully restore
your wallet in a different software which is strictly following BIP-44.

Beside, using large gaps is **not recommended** as it may induce important performance degradations. Use at your own risks.

oneOf.title: icarus/trezor/ledger (from xpub)

oneOf.description: patate

encrypted_root_private_key.description:
A root private key, encrypted using a given passphrase. The underlying key should contain:
- A private key
- A chain code
- A public key

passphrase_hash.description:
A hash of master passphrase. The hash should be an output of a Scrypt function with the following parameters:
- logN = 14
- r = 8
- p = 1

oneOf.title: random (from xprv)

x-parametersIntendedStakeAmount.name: stake
x-parametersIntendedStakeAmount.description: The stake the user intends to delegate in Lovelace. Required.

schema.description:
An individual segment within a derivation path.
Indexes without `H` suffix are called `Soft`.
Indexes with `H` suffix are called `Hardened`.

x-parametersStartDate.name: start
x-parametersStartDate.description:
An optional start time in ISO 8601 date-and-time format. Basic and
extended formats are both accepted. Times can be local (with a
timezone offset) or UTC.

If both a start time and an end time are specified, then the start
time must not be later than the end time.

Example: `2008-08-08T08:08:08Z`

x-parametersEndDate.name: end
x-parametersEndDate.description:
An optional end time in ISO 8601 date-and-time format. Basic and
extended formats are both accepted. Times can be local (with a
timezone offset) or UTC.

If both a start time and an end time are specified, then the start
time must not be later than the end time.

Example: `2008-08-08T08:08:08Z`

x-parametersAddressState.name: state
x-parametersAddressState.description: An optional filter on the address state.

x-parametersForceNtpCheck.name: forceNtpCheck
x-parametersForceNtpCheck.description:
NTP checks are cached for short duration to avoid sending too many queries to the central NTP servers. In some cases however, a client may want to force a new check.

When this flag is set, the request **will block** until NTP server responds or will timeout after a while without any answer from the NTP server.

x-parametersMinWithdrawal.name: minWithdrawal
x-parametersMinWithdrawal.description:
Returns only transactions that have at least one withdrawal above the given amount.
This is particularly useful when set to `1` in order to list the withdrawal history of a wallet.

May occur when an endpoint requires the presence of a query parameter that is missing.
May occur when trying to unregister a stake key that still has rewards attached to it.
May occur when a requested output is below the minimum utxo value.
May occur when trying to withdraw less than the minimal UTxO value.
May occur when submitting a withdrawal while another withdrawal is pending.
May occur when withdrawing an amount would cost more than the withdrawn value.

The amount of assets available to spend may be less than the total
unspent assets due to transaction change amounts which are yet to
be fully confirmed (pending).

metadata.title: Native Assets Metadata
metadata.description:
status: ⚠ under development

_This field is not implemented yet, and the values will always be empty._ In the Mary era of Cardano, UTxO may contain native assets. These assets are represented on-chain by opaque identifiers which are meaningless to end-users. Therefore, user-facing metadata regarding each token must be stored off-chain, in a metadata registry. Token creators may publish metadata into the registry and client applications can consume these metadata for display to end users. This will work in a similar way to how it is done for stake pool metadata.

name.description: A human-readable name for the asset. Good for display in user interfaces.

description.description: A human-readable description for the asset. Good for display in user interfaces.

acronym.description:
A human-readable short name for the asset. Good for display in
user interfaces.

unit.description:
Defines a larger unit for the asset, in the same way Ada is the
larger unit of Lovelace.

decimals.description: The number of digits after the decimal point.

name.description:
The human-readable name for the larger unit of the asset. Used
for display in user interfaces.

url.description: A URL to the policy's owner(s) or the entity website in charge of the asset.

logo.description:
A base64-encoded `image/png` for displaying the asset. The end image can be expected
to be smaller than 64KB.

Token creators may publish metadata into the registry and client applications can consume these metadata for display to end users. This will work in a similar way to how it is done for stake pool metadata.

name.description: A human-readable name for the asset. Good for display in user interfaces.

description.description: A human-readable description for the asset. Good for display in user interfaces.

acronym.description:
A human-readable short name for the asset. Good for display in
user interfaces.

unit.description:
Defines a larger unit for the asset, in the same way Ada is the
larger unit of Lovelace.

decimals.description: The number of digits after the decimal point.

name.description:
The human-readable name for the larger unit of the asset. Used
for display in user interfaces.

url.description: A URL to the policy's owner(s) or the entity website in charge of the asset.

logo.description:
A base64-encoded `image/png` for displaying the asset. The end image can be expected
to be smaller than 64KB.

message.description: May occur when providing an invalid 'Accept' header.

id.description: A unique identifier for the wallet

available.description: Available balance (funds that can be spent)

total.description: Total balance (available balance plus pending change)

assets.description:
Current non-Ada asset holdings of the wallet.

The amount of assets available to spend may be less than the total
unspent assets due to transaction change amounts which are yet to
be fully confirmed (pending).

items.description:
An asset on the Cardano blockchain. An asset is uniquely identified by
its `policy_id` and `asset_name` (together, these form the _asset id_).

Two assets with the same `asset_name` and `policy_id` are
interchangeable. Yet, different assets with a same `policy_id` but
different `asset_name` are treated as separate assets, as are two
assets with the same `asset_name` but different `policy_id`.

policy_id.description:
A unique identifier of the asset's monetary policy. The policy
controls how assets of this kind are created and destroyed.

The contents are the blake2b-224 hash of the monetary policy
script, encoded in hexadecimal.

asset_name.description:
The asset on-chain type which acts as a sub-identifier within a
policy. Although we call it "asset name", the value needn't be
text, and it could even be empty.

For policies with a single fungible asset item, asset name is
typically an empty string.

This value can be up to 32 bytes of arbitrary data (which is 64
hexadecimal digits).

fingerprint.description:
A user-facing short fingerprint which combines the `policy_id` and `asset_name`
to allow for an easier human comparison of assets. Note that it is generally
**not okay** to use this fingerprint as a unique identifier for it is not collision
resistant. Yet within the context of a single wallet, it makes for a (rather)
short user-facing comparison mean.

quantity.description: Number of assets for the given `policy_id` and `asset_name`.

available.description:
Available UTxO asset balances (funds that can be spent without
condition).

items.description:
An asset on the Cardano blockchain. An asset is uniquely identified by
its `policy_id` and `asset_name` (together, these form the _asset id_).

interchangeable. Yet, different assets with a same `policy_id` but
different `asset_name` are treated as separate assets, as are two
assets with the same `asset_name` but different `policy_id`.

state.description: Whether a wallet is ready to use or still syncing

message.description:
May occur when a given walletId does not match with any known
wallets (because it has been deleted, or has never existed).
May occur when providing an invalid 'Accept' header.

total.description: Coins, in Lovelace. Only relates to 'Ada'. Refer to `assets` for multi-assets wallets instead.

message.description:
May occur when a request is not well-formed; that is, it fails to parse
successfully. This could be the case when some required parameters
are missing or, when malformed values are provided.
May occur when providing an invalid 'Accept' header.
May occur when a otherwise valid request would yield a wallet that already exists.
May occur when providing an invalid 'Content-Type' header.

id.description: A unique identifier for the wallet

address_pool_gap.description:
Number of consecutive unused addresses allowed.

**IMPORTANT DISCLAIMER:** Using values other than `20` automatically makes your wallet invalid with regards to BIP-44 address discovery. It means that you **will not** be able to fully restore
your wallet in a different software which is strictly following BIP-44.

Beside, using large gaps is **not recommended** as it may induce important performance degradations. Use at your own risks.

unspent assets due to transaction change amounts which are yet to
be fully confirmed (pending).

id.description: A unique identifier for this transaction

amount.description:
An amount of Ada spent or received, from the perspective of the wallet.

That is, for outgoing transaction, it represents the amount of Ada consumed
as inputs, minus the amount of Ada spent as fees, as deposits or to addresses
which do not belong to the wallet.

For incoming transaction, it represents the total amount of Ada received to
addresses that belong to the wallet.

fee.description: Coins, in Lovelace. Only relates to 'Ada'. Refer to `assets` for multi-assets wallets instead.

deposit.description: Coins, in Lovelace. Only relates to 'Ada'. Refer to `assets` for multi-assets wallets instead.

inserted_at.description: A reference to a particular time slot, and the block height at that point.

absolute_slot_number.description: The 0-based slot index starting from genesis of the blockchain.

slot_number.description: The zero-based slot index within an epoch.

epoch_number.description: An epoch is a time period which is divided into slots.

expires_at.description: A reference to a particular time slot.

absolute_slot_number.description: The 0-based slot index starting from genesis of the blockchain.

epoch_number.description: An epoch is a time period which is divided into slots.

slot_number.description: The zero-based slot index within an epoch.

pending_since.description: A reference to a particular time slot, and the block height at that point.

absolute_slot_number.description: The 0-based slot index starting from genesis of the blockchain.

slot_number.description: The zero-based slot index within an epoch.

epoch_number.description: An epoch is a time period which is divided into slots.

A list of transaction inputs.

`assets` and `address` are always present for `outgoing`
transactions but generally absent for `incoming`
transactions. This information is present on the Cardano explorer,
but is not tracked by the wallet.

policy_id.description:
A unique identifier of the asset's monetary policy. The policy
controls how assets of this kind are created and destroyed.

The contents are the blake2b-224 hash of the monetary policy
script, encoded in hexadecimal.

asset_name.description:
The asset on-chain type which acts as a sub-identifier within a
policy. Although we call it "asset name", the value needn't be
text, and it could even be empty.

For policies with a single fungible asset item, asset name is
typically an empty string.

This value can be up to 32 bytes of arbitrary data (which is 64
hexadecimal digits).

fingerprint.description:
A user-facing short fingerprint which combines the `policy_id` and `asset_name`
to allow for an easier human comparison of assets. Note that it is generally
**not okay** to use this fingerprint as a unique identifier for it is not collision
resistant. Yet within the context of a single wallet, it makes for a (rather)
short user-facing comparison mean.

Positive values mean creation and negative values mean
destruction.

metadata.description:
**⚠️ WARNING ⚠️**

_Please note that metadata provided in a transaction will be
stored on the blockchain forever. Make sure not to include any sensitive data,
in particular personally identifiable information (PII)._

Extra application data attached to the transaction.

Cardano allows users and developers to embed their own
authenticated metadata when submitting transactions. Metadata can
be expressed as a JSON object with some restrictions:

1. All top-level keys must be integers between `0` and `2^64 - 1`.

2. Each metadata value is tagged with its type.

3. Strings must be at most 64 bytes when UTF-8 encoded.

4. Bytestrings are hex-encoded, with a maximum length of 64 bytes.

Metadata aren't stored as JSON on the Cardano blockchain but are
instead stored using a compact binary encoding (CBOR).

The binary encoding of metadata values supports three simple types:

* Integers in the range `-(2^64 - 1)` to `2^64 - 1`
* Strings (UTF-8 encoded)
* Bytestrings

And two compound types:

* Lists of metadata values
* Mappings from metadata values to metadata values

It is possible to transform any JSON object into this schema.

However, if your application uses floating point values, they will
need to be converted somehow, according to your
requirements. Likewise for `null` or `bool` values. When reading
metadata from chain, be aware that integers may exceed the
javascript numeric range, and may need special "bigint" parsing.

May occur when a request is not well-formed; that is, it fails to parse
successfully. This could be the case when some required parameters
are missing or, when malformed values are provided.

May occur when a given walletId does not match with any known
wallets (because it has been deleted, or has never existed).
May occur when providing an invalid 'Accept' header.

id.description: A unique identifier for the wallet

address_pool_gap.description:
Number of consecutive unused addresses allowed.

**IMPORTANT DISCLAIMER:** Using values other than `20` automatically makes your wallet invalid with regards to BIP-44 address discovery. It means that you **will not** be able to fully restore
your wallet in a different software which is strictly following BIP-44.

Beside, using large gaps is **not recommended** as it may induce important performance degradations. Use at your own risks.

available.description: Available Ada UTxO balance (funds that can be spent without condition).

reward.description: The Ada balance of the reward account for this wallet.

total.description: Total Ada balance (available balance plus pending change and reward balance).

assets.description:
Current non-Ada asset holdings of the wallet.

The amount of assets available to spend may be less than the total
unspent assets due to transaction change amounts which are yet to
be fully confirmed (pending).

items.description:
An asset on the Cardano blockchain. An asset is uniquely identified by
its `policy_id` and `asset_name` (together, these form the _asset id_).

Two assets with the same `asset_name` and `policy_id` are
interchangeable. Yet, different assets with a same `policy_id` but
different `asset_name` are treated as separate assets, as are two
assets with the same `asset_name` but different `policy_id`.

policy_id.description:
A unique identifier of the asset's monetary policy. The policy
controls how assets of this kind are created and destroyed.

The contents are the blake2b-224 hash of the monetary policy
script, encoded in hexadecimal.

asset_name.description:

policy. Although we call it "asset name", the value needn't be
text, and it could even be empty.

For policies with a single fungible asset item, asset name is
typically an empty string.

This value can be up to 32 bytes of arbitrary data (which is 64
hexadecimal digits).

A user-facing short fingerprint which combines the `policy_id` and `asset_name`
to allow for an easier human comparison of assets. Note that it is generally
**not okay** to use this fingerprint as a unique identifier for it is not collision
resistant. Yet within the context of a single wallet, it makes for a (rather)
short user-facing comparison mean.

message.description:
May occur when a request is not well-formed; that is, it fails to parse
successfully. This could be the case when some required parameters
are missing or, when malformed values are provided.
May occur when an action require a signing key but the wallet has only access to verification keys.
May occur when the given spending passphrase is wrong.

May occur when a given walletId does not match with any known
wallets (because it has been deleted, or has never existed).
May occur when providing an invalid 'Accept' header.
May occur when providing an invalid 'Content-Type' header.

May occur when a request is not well-formed; that is, it fails to parse
successfully. This could be the case when some required parameters
are missing or, when malformed values are provided.
May occur when submitting a withdrawal while another withdrawal is pending.
May occur when a requested output is below the minimum utxo value.
May occur when there's not enough money in the wallet to cover a requested payment.
May occur when a transaction can't be balanced for fees.
May occur when there's enough money to pay for a payment, but not enough UTxO to allow for paying each output independently.
Should never happen unless the server screwed up with the creation of a coin selection.

May occur when a given walletId does not match with any known
wallets (because it has been deleted, or has never existed).
May occur when providing an invalid 'Accept' header.
May occur when providing an invalid 'Content-Type' header.

amount.description:
An amount of Ada spent or received, from the perspective of the wallet.

That is, for outgoing transaction, it represents the amount of Ada consumed
as inputs, minus the amount of Ada spent as fees, as deposits or to addresses
which do not belong to the wallet.

For incoming transaction, it represents the total amount of Ada received to
addresses that belong to the wallet.

metadata.description:
**⚠️ WARNING ⚠️**

_Please note that metadata provided in a transaction will be
stored on the blockchain forever. Make sure not to include any sensitive data,
in particular personally identifiable information (PII)._

Extra application data attached to the transaction.

Cardano allows users and developers to embed their own
authenticated metadata when submitting transactions. Metadata can
be expressed as a JSON object with some restrictions:

1. All top-level keys must be integers between `0` and `2^64 - 1`.

2. Each metadata value is tagged with its type.

3. Strings must be at most 64 bytes when UTF-8 encoded.

4. Bytestrings are hex-encoded, with a maximum length of 64 bytes.

Metadata aren't stored as JSON on the Cardano blockchain but are
instead stored using a compact binary encoding (CBOR).

The binary encoding of metadata values supports three simple types:

* Integers in the range `-(2^64 - 1)` to `2^64 - 1`
* Strings (UTF-8 encoded)
* Bytestrings

And two compound types:

* Lists of metadata values
* Mappings from metadata values to metadata values

It is possible to transform any JSON object into this schema.

However, if your application uses floating point values, they will
need to be converted somehow, according to your
requirements. Likewise for `null` or `bool` values. When reading
metadata from chain, be aware that integers may exceed the
javascript numeric range, and may need special "bigint" parsing.

message.description:
May occur when a request is not well-formed; that is, it fails to parse
successfully. This could be the case when some required parameters
are missing or, when malformed values are provided.
May occur when trying to perform an operation not supported by this type of wallet.
May occur when submitting a withdrawal while another withdrawal is pending.
May occur when a requested output is below the minimum utxo value.
May occur when a transaction can't be balanced for fees.
May occur when there's not enough money in the wallet to cover a requested payment.
May occur when the wallet can't cover for all requested outputs without making the transaction too large.
May occur when an action require a signing key but the wallet has only access to verification keys.
May occur when the given spending passphrase is wrong.

May occur when a given walletId does not match with any known
wallets (because it has been deleted, or has never existed).
May occur when providing an invalid 'Accept' header.
May occur when providing an invalid 'Content-Type' header.

addresses that belong to the wallet.

id.description: A unique identifier for the pool.

non_myopic_member_rewards.description:
The rewards the wallet can expect to receive at the end of an epoch, in the long term, if delegating to
this pool.

For more details, see the
[Design Specification for Delegation and Incentives in Cardano](https://hydra.iohk.io/job/Cardano/cardano-ledger-specs/delegationDesignSpec/latest/download-by-type/doc-pdf/delegation_design_spec)
document.

relative_stake.description:
The live pool stake relative to the *total* stake.

For more details, see the section "Relative Stake: Active vs Total" in
[Design Specification for Delegation and Incentives in Cardano](https://hydra.iohk.io/job/Cardano/cardano-ledger-specs/delegationDesignSpec/latest/download-by-type/doc-pdf/delegation_design_spec).

saturation.description:
Saturation-level of the pool based on the desired number of pools aimed by the network.
A value above `1` indicates that the pool is saturated.

The `non_myopic_member_rewards` take oversaturation into account, as specified by the [specs](https://hydra.iohk.io/job/Cardano/cardano-ledger-specs/delegationDesignSpec/latest/download-by-type/doc-pdf/delegation_design_spec).

The saturation is based on the live `relative_stake`. The saturation at the end of epoch e,
will affect the rewards paid out at the end of epoch e+3.

produced_blocks.description: Number of blocks produced by a given stake pool in its lifetime.

cost.description:
Estimated cost set by the pool operator when registering his pool.
This fixed cost is taken from each reward earned by the pool before splitting rewards between stakeholders.

May be omitted if the wallet hasn't found the pool's registration cerificate yet.

margin.description:
Variable margin on the total reward given to an operator before splitting rewards between stakeholders.

May be omitted if the wallet hasn't found the pool's registration cerificate yet.

pledge.description:
Minimal stake amount that a stake pool is willing to honor.

May be omitted if the wallet hasn't found the pool's registration cerificate yet.

metadata.description: Information about the stake pool.

epoch_number.description: An epoch is a time period which is divided into slots.

retirement.description:
The epoch in which a stake pool retires.

May be omitted if the wallet hasn't yet found a retirement certificate
for this stake pool.

flags.description:
Various flags applicable to stake pools. Possible flags:

| flag     | description                                                                                                      |
| ---      | ---                                                                                                              |
| delisted | The pool is marked as delisted on a configured SMASH server; metadata for this pool have therefore been dropped. |

message.description: A descriptive error message.

code.description: A specific error code for this error, more precise than HTTP ones.

gc_stake_pools.description:
Gives an indication if metadata GC checking for delisted pools
has run and if so, when.

Possible values are:
  - not_applicable -> we're currently not querying a SMASH server for metadata
  - not_started -> the GC hasn't started yet, try again in a short while
  - restarting -> the GC thread is currently restarting, try again in short while
  - has_run -> the GC has run successfully

When 'status' is 'restarting' or 'has_run' then the field 'last_run'
is set to the last GC time in UTC.

message.description:
May occur when a request is not well-formed; that is, it fails to parse
successfully. This could be the case when some required parameters
are missing or, when malformed values are provided.
May occur when a transaction can't be balanced for fees.
May occur when an action require a signing key but the wallet has only access to verification keys.
May occur when the given spending passphrase is wrong.
May occur when a given poolId matches the current delegation preferences of the wallet's account.

May occur when a given walletId does not match with any known
wallets (because it has been deleted, or has never existed).
May occur when a given poolId does not match any known pool.
May occur when providing an invalid 'Accept' header.
May occur when providing an invalid 'Content-Type' header.

Current depth of the transaction in the local chain

inputs.description:
A list of transaction inputs.

`assets` and `address` are always present for `outgoing`
transactions but generally absent for `incoming`
transactions. This information is present on the Cardano explorer,
but is not tracked by the wallet.

amount.description: Coins, in Lovelace. Only relates to 'Ada'. Refer to `assets` for multi-assets wallets instead.

items.description:
An asset on the Cardano blockchain. An asset is uniquely identified by
its `policy_id` and `asset_name` (together, these form the _asset id_).

Two assets with the same `asset_name` and `policy_id` are
interchangeable. Yet, different assets with a same `policy_id` but
different `asset_name` are treated as separate assets, as are two
assets with the same `asset_name` but different `policy_id`.

policy_id.description:
A unique identifier of the asset's monetary policy. The policy
controls how assets of this kind are created and destroyed.

The contents are the blake2b-224 hash of the monetary policy
script, encoded in hexadecimal.

asset_name.description:
The asset on-chain type which acts as a sub-identifier within a
policy. Although we call it "asset name", the value needn't be
text, and it could even be empty.

For policies with a single fungible asset item, asset name is
typically an empty string.

This value can be up to 32 bytes of arbitrary data (which is 64
hexadecimal digits).

fingerprint.description:
A user-facing short fingerprint which combines the `policy_id` and `asset_name`
to allow for an easier human comparison of assets. Note that it is generally
**not okay** to use this fingerprint as a unique identifier for it is not collision
resistant. Yet within the context of a single wallet, it makes for a (rather)
short user-facing comparison mean.

metadata.description:
**⚠️ WARNING ⚠️**

_Please note that metadata provided in a transaction will be
stored on the blockchain forever. Make sure not to include any sensitive data,
in particular personally identifiable information (PII)._

Extra application data attached to the transaction.

Cardano allows users and developers to embed their own
authenticated metadata when submitting transactions. Metadata can
be expressed as a JSON object with some restrictions:

1. All top-level keys must be integers between `0` and `2^64 - 1`.

2. Each metadata value is tagged with its type.

3. Strings must be at most 64 bytes when UTF-8 encoded.

4. Bytestrings are hex-encoded, with a maximum length of 64 bytes.

Metadata aren't stored as JSON on the Cardano blockchain but are
instead stored using a compact binary encoding (CBOR).

The binary encoding of metadata values supports three simple types:

* Integers in the range `-(2^64 - 1)` to `2^64 - 1`
* Strings (UTF-8 encoded)
* Bytestrings

And two compound types:

* Lists of metadata values
* Mappings from metadata values to metadata values

It is possible to transform any JSON object into this schema.

However, if your application uses floating point values, they will
need to be converted somehow, according to your
requirements. Likewise for `null` or `bool` values. When reading
metadata from chain, be aware that integers may exceed the
javascript numeric range, and may need special "bigint" parsing.

eras.description:
If and when each era started or will start.

The object is keyed by era names. The values either describe the epoch boundary
when the era starts (can be in the future or in the past), or are null if not yet
confirmed on-chain.

If you need to know the current era, see the `node_era` field of
`GET /network/information`.

> Due to complications with our current tooling, we cannot mark the era names
> as required, but the keys are in fact always present.

schema.description:
The status of the SMASH server. Possible values are:

health                  | description
---                     | ---
`"available"`           | server is awaiting your requests
`"unavailable"`         | server is running, but currently unavailable, try again in a short time
`"unreachable"`         | server could not be reached or didn't return a health status
`"no_smash_configured"` | SMASH is currently not configured, adjust the Settings first

address_pool_gap.description:
Number of consecutive unused addresses allowed.

**IMPORTANT DISCLAIMER:** Using values other than `20` automatically makes your wallet invalid with regards to BIP-44 address discovery. It means that you **will not** be able to fully restore
your wallet in a different software which is strictly following BIP-44.

Beside, using large gaps is **not recommended** as it may induce important performance degradations. Use at your own risks.

metadata.title: Native Assets Metadata
metadata.description:
status: ⚠ under development

_This field is not implemented yet, and the values will always be empty._ In the Mary era of Cardano, UTxO may contain native assets. These assets are represented on-chain by opaque identifiers which are meaningless to end-users. Therefore, user-facing metadata regarding each token must be stored off-chain, in a metadata registry. Token creators may publish metadata into the registry and client applications can consume these metadata for display to end users. This will work in a similar way to how it is done for stake pool metadata.

name.description: A human-readable name for the asset. Good for display in user interfaces.

description.description: A human-readable description for the asset. Good for display in user interfaces.

acronym.description:
A human-readable short name for the asset. Good for display in
user interfaces.

unit.description:
Defines a larger unit for the asset, in the same way Ada is the
larger unit of Lovelace.

decimals.description: The number of digits after the decimal point.

name.description:
The human-readable name for the larger unit of the asset. Used
for display in user interfaces.

url.description: A URL to the policy's owner(s) or the entity website in charge of the asset.

logo.description:
A base64-encoded `image/png` for displaying the asset. The end image can be expected
to be smaller than 64KB.

status: under development

metadata.title: Native Assets Metadata
metadata.description:
status: ⚠ under development

_This field is not implemented yet, and the values will always be empty._ In the Mary era of Cardano, UTxO may contain native assets. These assets are represented on-chain by opaque identifiers which are meaningless to end-users. Therefore, user-facing metadata regarding each token must be stored off-chain, in a metadata registry. Token creators may publish metadata into the registry and client applications can consume these metadata for display to end users. This will work in a similar way to how it is done for stake pool metadata.

post.description:
status: stable

Estimate fee for the transaction. The estimate is made by assembling multiple transactions and analyzing the distribution of their fees. The estimated_max is the highest fee observed, and the estimated_min is the fee which is lower than at least 90% of the fees observed.

quantity.description: Number of assets for the given `policy_id` and `asset_name`.

withdrawal.description:
When provided, instruments the server to automatically withdraw rewards from the source wallet when they are deemed
sufficient (i.e. they contribute to the balance for at least as much as they cost).

As a consequence, the resulting transaction may or may not have a withdrawal object. Summarizing:

withdrawal field | reward balance | result
---              | ---            | ---
`null`           | too small      | ✓ no withdrawals generated
`null`           | big enough     | ✓ no withdrawals generated
`"self"`         | too small      | ✓ no withdrawals generated
`"self"`         | big enough     | ✓ withdrawal generated

metadata.description:
**⚠️ WARNING ⚠️**

_Please note that metadata provided in a transaction will be
stored on the blockchain forever. Make sure not to include any sensitive data,
in particular personally identifiable information (PII)._

Extra application data attached to the transaction.

Cardano allows users and developers to embed their own
authenticated metadata when submitting transactions. Metadata can
be expressed as a JSON object with some restrictions:

1. All top-level keys must be integers between `0` and `2^64 - 1`.

2. Each metadata value is tagged with its type.

3. Strings must be at most 64 bytes when UTF-8 encoded.

4. Bytestrings are hex-encoded, with a maximum length of 64 bytes.

Metadata aren't stored as JSON on the Cardano blockchain but are
instead stored using a compact binary encoding (CBOR).

The binary encoding of metadata values supports three simple types:

* Integers in the range `-(2^64 - 1)` to `2^64 - 1`
* Strings (UTF-8 encoded)
* Bytestrings

And two compound types:

* Lists of metadata values
* Mappings from metadata values to metadata values

It is possible to transform any JSON object into this schema.

However, if your application uses floating point values, they will
need to be converted somehow, according to your
requirements. Likewise for `null` or `bool` values. When reading
metadata from chain, be aware that integers may exceed the
javascript numeric range, and may need special "bigint" parsing.

time_to_live.description:
The TTL (time to live) is the time period in which the transaction
will be accepted into node mempools.

After the TTL has lapsed, the transaction is considered
expired. At this point, nodes will give up on broadcasting the
transaction, and the wallet will release the funds allocated to
the transaction so they can be used for other payments.

The TTL should be long enough that the transaction has time to be
propagated through the network and confirmed, but short enough so
that - in the event of failures - UTxO are returned to the wallet
in a timely manner.

The TTL value is given in seconds. It will be converted to a slot
number internally.

If the TTL is not provided for a payment, a reasonable default
value will be used.

amount.description: Coins, in Lovelace. Only relates to 'Ada'. Refer to `assets` for multi-assets wallets instead.

items.description:
An asset on the Cardano blockchain. An asset is uniquely identified by
its `policy_id` and `asset_name` (together, these form the _asset id_).

Two assets with the same `asset_name` and `policy_id` are
interchangeable. Yet, different assets with a same `policy_id` but
different `asset_name` are treated as separate assets, as are two
assets with the same `asset_name` but different `policy_id`.

policy_id.description:
A unique identifier of the asset's monetary policy. The policy
controls how assets of this kind are created and destroyed.

The contents are the blake2b-224 hash of the monetary policy
script, encoded in hexadecimal.

asset_name.description:
The asset on-chain type which acts as a sub-identifier within a
policy. Although we call it "asset name", the value needn't be
text, and it could even be empty.

For policies with a single fungible asset item, asset name is
typically an empty string.

This value can be up to 32 bytes of arbitrary data (which is 64
hexadecimal digits).

fingerprint.description:
A user-facing short fingerprint which combines the `policy_id` and `asset_name`
to allow for an easier human comparison of assets. Note that it is generally
**not okay** to use this fingerprint as a unique identifier for it is not collision
resistant. Yet within the context of a single wallet, it makes for a (rather)
short user-facing comparison mean.

quantity.description: Number of assets for the given `policy_id` and `asset_name`.

withdrawal.description:
When provided, attempts to withdraw rewards from the default stake address corresponding to the given mnemonic.

Should the rewards be null or too small to be worth withdrawing (i.e. the cost of adding them into the transaction
is more than their own intrinsic value), the server will reject the request with a `withdrawal_not_worth` error.

withdrawal field    | reward balance | result
---                 | ---            | ---
any recovery phrase | too small      | x Error 403 `withdrawal_not_worth`
any recovery phrase | big enough     | ✓ withdrawal generated

message.description:
May occur when a request is not well-formed; that is, it fails to parse
successfully. This could be the case when some required parameters
are missing or, when malformed values are provided.
May occur when trying to perform an operation not supported by this type of wallet.
May occur when submitting a withdrawal while another withdrawal is pending.
May occur when a requested output is below the minimum utxo value.
May occur when a transaction can't be balanced for fees.
May occur when there's not enough money in the wallet to cover a requested payment.
May occur when there's enough money to pay for a payment, but not enough UTxO to allow for paying each output independently.
Should never happen unless the server screwed up with the creation of a coin selection.
May occur when the wallet can't cover for all requested outputs without making the transaction too large.

May occur when a given walletId does not match with any known
wallets (because it has been deleted, or has never existed).
May occur when providing an invalid 'Accept' header.
May occur when providing an invalid 'Content-Type' header.

May occur when there's not enough money in the wallet to cover a requested payment.
May occur when the wallet can't cover for all requested outputs without making the transaction too large.
May occur when an action require a signing key but the wallet has only access to verification keys.
May occur when the given spending passphrase is wrong.

May occur when a given walletId does not match with any known
wallets (because it has been deleted, or has never existed).
May occur when providing an invalid 'Accept' header.
May occur when providing an invalid 'Content-Type' header.

which do not belong to the wallet.

For incoming transaction, it represents the total amount of Ada received to
addresses that belong to the wallet.

items.description:
An asset on the Cardano blockchain. An asset is uniquely identified by
its `policy_id` and `asset_name` (together, these form the _asset id_).

Two assets with the same `asset_name` and `policy_id` are
interchangeable. Yet, different assets with a same `policy_id` but
different `asset_name` are treated as separate assets, as are two
assets with the same `asset_name` but different `policy_id`.

policy_id.description:
A unique identifier of the asset's monetary policy. The policy
controls how assets of this kind are created and destroyed.

The contents are the blake2b-224 hash of the monetary policy
script, encoded in hexadecimal.

asset_name.description:
The asset on-chain type which acts as a sub-identifier within a
policy. Although we call it "asset name", the value needn't be
text, and it could even be empty.

For policies with a single fungible asset item, asset name is
typically an empty string.

This value can be up to 32 bytes of arbitrary data (which is 64
hexadecimal digits).

fingerprint.description:
A user-facing short fingerprint which combines the `policy_id` and `asset_name`
to allow for an easier human comparison of assets. Note that it is generally
**not okay** to use this fingerprint as a unique identifier for it is not collision
resistant. Yet within the context of a single wallet, it makes for a (rather)
short user-facing comparison mean.

metadata.description:
**⚠️ WARNING ⚠️**

_Please note that metadata provided in a transaction will be
stored on the blockchain forever. Make sure not to include any sensitive data,
in particular personally identifiable information (PII)._

Extra application data attached to the transaction.

Cardano allows users and developers to embed their own
authenticated metadata when submitting transactions. Metadata can
be expressed as a JSON object with some restrictions:

1. All top-level keys must be integers between `0` and `2^64 - 1`.

2. Each metadata value is tagged with its type.

3. Strings must be at most 64 bytes when UTF-8 encoded.

4. Bytestrings are hex-encoded, with a maximum length of 64 bytes.

Metadata aren't stored as JSON on the Cardano blockchain but are
instead stored using a compact binary encoding (CBOR).

The binary encoding of metadata values supports three simple types:

* Integers in the range `-(2^64 - 1)` to `2^64 - 1`
* Strings (UTF-8 encoded)
* Bytestrings

And two compound types:

* Lists of metadata values
* Mappings from metadata values to metadata values

It is possible to transform any JSON object into this schema.

However, if your application uses floating point values, they will
need to be converted somehow, according to your
requirements. Likewise for `null` or `bool` values. When reading
metadata from chain, be aware that integers may exceed the
javascript numeric range, and may need special "bigint" parsing.

get.description:
status: stable

Lists all incoming and outgoing wallet's transactions.

parameters.name: start
parameters.description:
An optional start time in ISO 8601 date-and-time format. Basic and
extended formats are both accepted. Times can be local (with a
timezone offset) or UTC.

If both a start time and an end time are specified, then the start
time must not be later than the end time.

Example: `2008-08-08T08:08:08Z`

parameters.name: end
parameters.description:
An optional end time in ISO 8601 date-and-time format. Basic and
extended formats are both accepted. Times can be local (with a
timezone offset) or UTC.

If both a start time and an end time are specified, then the start
time must not be later than the end time.

Example: `2008-08-08T08:08:08Z`

parameters.name: minWithdrawal
parameters.description:
Returns only transactions that have at least one withdrawal above the given amount.
This is particularly useful when set to `1` in order to list the withdrawal history of a wallet.
